head.title: New Hampshire Senate Votes To Allow Same-Sex Civil Unions

abstract.p: New Hampshire Senate votes to become fourth state to allow civil unions for same-sex couples; state is first to do so without court order or pending lawsuit; Gov John Lynch says he will sign bill (M)

block.p: A vote in the New Hampshire Senate on Thursday cleared the way for the state to become the fourth to allow civil unions for same-sex couples, and the first to do so without a court order or a pending lawsuit.

The Senate voted along party lines, 14 Democrats in favor and 10 Republicans against, passing a bill that gives couples in civil unions the same rights and benefits as married couples, and that recognizes legal same-sex marriages from other states or countries as civil unions.
A vote cleared the way for the state to become the fourth to allow the civil unions and the first to do so without a court order or pending lawsuit.

A vote in the New Hampshire Senate on Thursday cleared the way for the state to become the fourth to allow civil unions for same-sex couples, and the first to do so without a court order or a pending lawsuit.

The Senate voted along party lines, 14 Democrats in favor and 10 Republicans against, passing a bill that gives couples in civil unions the same rights and benefits as married couples, and that recognizes legal same-sex marriages from other states or countries as civil unions.

Gov. John Lynch, a Democrat, said last week that he would sign the bill, saying it was a matter of promoting fairness and preventing discrimination. The bill passed the New Hampshire House this month. Its passage reflects a sea change in New Hampshire politics, which in 2006 elected Democratic majorities in both state chambers for the first time in more than a century.

''It's a bill dealing with fairness and equality, and it also sends a strong message that discrimination will not be the policy of the state,'' said Senator Joseph A. Foster, a Democrat. ''We did not do it as result of some court someplace telling us to do so, but we did so because it's the right thing to do.''

Mr. Foster said being a neighbor to Vermont, which has had civil unions for seven years, had convinced him that ''what civil unions do is it affects same-gendered couples who are in committed relationships, but I haven't seen any evidence that it affects anybody else.''
Senator Robert Letourneau, a Republican, said opposing civil unions was not discriminatory.

''We do put limits on what we allow in the state as far as other things,'' Mr. Letourneau said. ''You cannot marry your cousins; we don't let blind people drive; we don't let felons vote. I wasn't allowed to join the service because I had punctured eardrums. Was I discriminated against?''

He said the law would be ''opening up a Pandora's box'' of repercussions, including pressures on schools to teach about gay men and lesbians, problems for businesses in providing benefits to same-sex couples and violations of the military's ''don't ask don't tell'' policy, because ''if you engage in a civil union it will be public record, and everybody will know because you told.''

In addition to Vermont, Connecticut and New Jersey allow civil unions. Massachusetts is the only state that allows same-sex marriage. But New York's governor, Eliot Spitzer, a Democrat, said this week that he planned to introduce legislation to allow same-sex couples to marry.
